WRITING.TEXT: That isn't deductive reasoning, and it certainly isn't evidence. That's just speculation and appealing to data that you don't have.
Do you have any evidence that Supergirl isn't getting online viewers like Arrow is?
[Meanwhile on ABC...](http://cdn.abclocal.go.com/content/ktrk/images/cms/1036198_1280x720.jpg)
That would explain [in part] why ratings fell after the first two episodes of the season, not why they're fallen in recent weeks.

* [The Grinder](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/the-grinder-season-one-ratings-38238/): permiered to a 1.52 with 4.98 million viewers. Its penultimate episode did a 0.52 with 1.51 million. * [Grandfathered](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/grandfathered-season-one-ratings-38240/): premiered to a 1.49 and 5.33 million; ended with a 0.65 and 1.64 million. * [Borderdown](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/bordertown-season-one-ratings/): premiered to a 1.13 and 2.34 million, increased to a 1.48 and 3.58 million in its second episode; ended with a 0.45 and 1.159 million (and went below that a number of times prior) * [Cooper Barrett](http://tvseriesfinale.com/tv-show/cooper-barretts-guide-to-surviving-life-season-one-ratings/): premiered to a 1.139and 2.62 million, increased to a 2.07 and 4.57 million in its second episode; did a 0.44 and 1.037 million before getting pulled.
None of these shows were picking up steam, they all declined severely in viewership over the course of their first season and ended with very poor numbers. I don't see how it's likely that any, let alone all, of them would have dramatically reversed course and risen back to decent numbers had they been renewed.
FX is a cable channel so they have a different business model than Fox's broadcast channel. Anyways FX has shown itself willing to cancel freshman shows that aren't performing well (Bastard Executioner, he Comedians, Saint George, Partners, etc).
Pushing Daisies still got renewed even with the strike.

But if you compare Supergirl's 2nd season to Arrow's 2nd season
You can't compare a current season to a season from three years ago without accounting for the overall drop in broadcast ratings that happens every year. Adjusting for that puts Supergirl S2 about on par with Arrow S2.
That said, Supergirl's ratings definitely seem to be declining more than average. For much of the season Supergirl was a clear number 2 on the CW behind only the Flash, but these last two weeks put it at the same level as Arrow and Supernatural (and LoT when it was still airing), even with those shows' ratings also declining over the course of the season.

Rating itself stayed the same, viewer count dipped:
The demo rating is down a few hundredths in unrounded numbers.

Flash and Arrow went on the same hiatus (and there have been plenty of promos for all three during the break). Flash returned up 0.14 from the previous episode, Arrow returned down 0.06 (and only down 0.01 from two episodes prior, which had been the season low). Supergirl returned down 0.18 from its previous episode and didn't rebound at all this week. I don't think we can blame this solely on the hiatus.
Who says networks are ignoring stuff like online viewership numbers?
Lots of people like to blame the strike for Heroes' downfall. Doesn't mean the strike was actually responsible.
You can't legally stream the CW in Europe; the CW only operates in the US.
Heroes lasted for two years after the last strike; it fell apart all on its own.

As far as DVR goes, if you're watching within 3 or 7 days then it matters whether or not you're skipping the commercials. Commercials are sold based on C3 and C7 ratings that count delayed views within 3 or 7 days but only where the commercials weren't skipped; L+3 and L+7 don't matter for commercial prices (however they would for product placement, though I don't know how exactly the pricing for that works).

Just fast forward if you dont wanna see two guys kiss.
It's seemingly always two women when it comes to gay couples actually showing physical affection, I can't recall two guys kissing in any of the CW shows (at least recently).

It's the CW, most of the drama feels pretty forced, and their DC shows in particular tend to lack subtlety.
Also Gotham isn't a CW show.

I'm pretty sure that's been a thing for a while, at least in Season 2.
It's been a thing since S1E1; the DEO knew who Kara was shortly after she first arrived on Earth.
Even if you're part of the very small percentage of the population not reached by a Fox broadcast signal, Fox's website/app is still free to use.

Are you being intentionally obtuse, or what?
To say that things always get larger *upon heating* would be incorrect, because negative thermal expansion is possible. However to say that things always get larger when they expand is true *by definition*.
Don't need cable to watch Fox.

I will never understand why.
Ratings. Ratings are why.
GoT should be fine unless a strike goes on for quite some time, and even then HBO could just delay it since they're not bound to as rigid a schedule as the broadcast networks.

And I still saw ads for Pitch back when it was still airing in the fall.
Also Gotham just came back from a three month hiatus, so I would expect it to have been getting more promotion than usual recently.

They didn't stop promoting it; they did back off its marketing after the premiere but that's the case for pretty much every show.
Now there's a decent argument that its timeslot was a poor choice, but I doubt changing timeslots would do much at this point.
Its ratings weren't particularly promising
It'll finish the same week as Flash and Arrow; it started a week later than them.
Eobard took Time Vault Gideon back towards the end of S1

The strike didn't kill Heroes' ratings; S3 premiered to similar viewership as most of S2. That the show went downhill after that is a separate issue, and from what I can gather it appears there were significant behind-the-scenes issues involving writing/production in season 3.
Yes. This has been true since S1E1, it's not a new development.
Firefly was cancelled 4 years before the last strike happened, and Heroes continued for two more seasons after the strike.

In comparison here's [ProCyclingStats' list of the top 100 cyclists of all time.](https://www.procyclingstats.com/rankings.php?id=4210 page=2 id=4210 nation= team= page=1 prev_entry_id=1346 younger= older= ApplyFilter=Filter) As far as I can tell Quintana is the only rider on that list that isn't white, and the only other non-Europeans on there are three Aussies, two Americans (though for comparison's sake Lance should probably be included making it three), and Vino (if he counts).

Please ensure that your comments do not violate the rules of this subreddit.

Those could arguably be sitcoms but I'd classify them more as dramedies, and notably they're hour-long shows rather than the traditional half-hour sitcom such as Powerless. Granted CEG was originally going to be a half-hour show for Showtime and was then reworked heavily to be an hour-long for the CW, but I don't see something like that working for Powerless.

You can't start a sentance with a conjunction.
You can absolutely start a sentence with a conjunction. Per the Chicago Manual of Style:
There is a widespread beliefone with no historical or grammatical foundationthat it is an error to begin a sentence with a conjunction such as *and*, *but* or *so*. In fact, a substantial percentage (often as many as 10 percent) of the sentences in first-rate writing begin with conjunctions. It has been so for centuries, and even the most conservative grammarians have followed this practice.
[Here's Wikipedia's section on the subject,](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conjunction_(grammar\)#Starting_a_sentence) and if you search 'conjunction starting sentence' you will find a multitude of other sources saying the same thing.
Perhaps you should make sure your notions of grammatical rules are in fact accurate before you accuse others of having incorrect grammar.

NBC can't sell the rights to the CW. NBC's options are to renew it or not; if they opt not to renew it then WB can shop the show around to other networks such as the CW.
That said the CW is not likely to pick it up, both since the CW currently doesn't do sitcoms and since Powerless was reportedly very expensive.

Well every show takes weeks off, but yeah airing episodes out of order was stupid. However once that was done there was no way to undo it, leaving cancellation as the only reasonable option *at that point*.

A second season is typically when a show finds itself and the audience begins to stablize somewhat.
Changing networks after the first season is going to screw with that. And very few shows change networks after one season, putting Supergirl in a somewhat unique situation.
For recent shows that have similar ratings trajectories to Supergirl, Quantico on ABC is the first that comes to mind: S1 premiered with a 1.93 and 7.142 million, ended with a 1.04 and 3.783 million; S2 premiered with a 0.96 and 3.635 million, most recent episode was 0.5 and 2.592 million.

Pretty sure its still the 2nd highest rated show on the CW this season.
On average, yes. But this 0.5 matches the season lows of Arrow, LoT, and Supernatural (in rounded numbers, as we don't have unrounded finals yet for this episode).
That is a perfectly acceptable sentence. Sure, it's not anything particularly elegant, but it's grammatically correct.

Firefly did terribly and anyone looking at those numbers would have dropped it
As far as I can tell no one on reddit complaining about shows getting cancelled ever actually looks at the numbers.
A 0.5 matches the season lows of Arrow, LoT, and Supernatural; earlier in the season Supergirl was a clear-cut second place on the CW behind only The Flash and decently ahead of the rest.
And yet it didn't hurt the Flash's ratings.

Chuck and Community also never got good ratings (particularly Community) and Chuck wasn't produced by NBC so NBC only made money off it via ad sales, not syndication and DVD sales and whatnot. Harsh treatment of poorly-performing shows, particularly from outside studios, is not Brita-ing them, it's good business.

but it's making huge money for The CW overseas (the Netflix deal)
We don't know how much Riverdale's Netflix deal is worth, both in general and compared to the international distribution deals for other CW shows.
Scrubs ran for 7 seasons (on NBC), Community and Chuck for 5, Hannibal for 3 despite poor ratings in S1 and abysmal ratings in S2. Those shows were not Brita'd by NBC.
There's been plenty of marketing, and Riverdale may be getting buzz but it's not really translating into ratings. But otherwise, yeah.
The show was dead in the water (in terms of ratings) before any of the schedule and episode order changes happened.
Season 7 will be unaffected; season 8 could be affected if a strike happens and goes long enough.
Pushing Daisies survived the last strike, it got cancelled the season after that because (like seemingly every Bryan Fuller show) it couldn't sustain decent viewership numbers.
Vixen is just a half-hour per season

What makes you say it would dry up?
Because the people that own the content won't continue licensing it cheaply after they saw Netflix's success with streaming, they'll either greatly increase the license fee or pull it to use on their own streaming service. This is exactly what's happening and it was really easy to foresee, which is why Netflix has pushing to expand their library of originals so that it can survive a massive reduction in licensed content.
Netflix wants to do that because they know that their supply of licensed content is going to dry up.
B99 has already been sold to syndication. But its syndication deal includes a fifth season, should it get one, which should help its renewal chances.

Agents of Shield *is currently in syndication*; it was sold to syndication on MyNetworkTV a year ago and began airing there last September.
88 episodes is the standard threshold for syndication these days, but it's not a hard limit (for instance ABC cancelled Nashville last year after 4 seasons and 86 episodes, at which point it was already sold to syndication).

The only reason they are keeping it around is to reach syndication next season and also as a lead in for the new inhumans series
It's already reached syndication, and ABC isn't going to use a show getting fractional ratings as a lead-in for something as big as Inhumans.

That doesn't disagree with what I said. Pushing Daisies got renewed in spite of the first season being shortened by the strike and returned to viewership only slightly lower than its S1 finale. However its viewership continued to decline in S2, as it had in S1, leading to its cancellation. I'm not seeing any strong evidence that the strike killed it.

SNL is on the list because (as the article said) it would likely have to cancel its last three episodes of this season if a strike started on May 1, since SNL isn't written weeks/months in advance of airing like most scripted shows.
Pushing Daisies survived the last strike. It then died of its own accord, because like Fuller's other shows it had a lot of critical praise but not a lot of actual viewers.

I think that was the only on screen casuality as well.
Excluding villains I think that might be the case.
Savitar is voiced by Tobin Bell

How was the writers strike responsible for Pushing Daisies getting cancelled? It still got renewed after its strike-shortened first season, and the S2 premiere drew only slightly fewer viewers than the S1 finale.
Minimally, provided it doesn't last overly long.

But a lot of TV shows wrapped up filming for fall premieres.

Because you don't need cable to watch TV.

Most reality shows are unscripted. Sure the directors/producers are often manipulating the participants, and the editing can further distort the 'reality' of what's going on, but that's not the same as having an actual written script.

Netflix doesn't produce most of its Originals, it commissions them from outside studios. So for them to cut out the WGA completely they would have to cancel many of their existing Originals that come from American studios.
Unscripted shows don't need writers.

So this has to imply that all of them will survive season 7

WRITING.TITLE: Supergirl S2E18 "Ace Reporter" Episode Discussion
WRITING.TEXT:
**Synopsis:** Lenas (guest star Katie McGarth) ex-boyfriend, Jack Spheer (guest star Rahul Kohli), comes to National City to unveil his big breakthrough in nano-technology, which has the potential to eradicate all diseases. Lena asks Kara to attend Jacks conference with her for support. When Kara sees Snapper (guest Star Ian Gomez) in attendance shes inspired to tap back into her reporter skills and questions Jack on his discovery, which ultimately leads to a bigger investigation that puts everyone in danger.
Director: Armen V. Kevorkian
Written By: Paula Yoo Caitlin Parrish
**Main Cast:**
* Melissa Benoist as Kara Zor-El / Kara Danvers / Supergirl * Mehcad Brooks as James Olsen * Chyler Leigh as Alex Danvers * Jeremy Jordan as Winn Schott * David Harewood as J'onn J'onzz / Hank Henshaw * Chris Wood as Mon-El * Floriana Lima as Maggie Sawyer

Lead actors like that will get paid whether they are in the episode or not.
Generally yes, but they are also still in the credits for those episodes. GoT has had episodes where main cast members are absent and not credited.

If the GoT actors took a lower salary the difference would just go to the studio/network, it wouldn't do anything for all the people who are barely getting by. Wealth inequality is an issue but calling these actors assholes for not taking a lower salary than they could is not the way to address it.
At least until they get killed

That's typically how it works for main cast members, but they're typically also credited in episodes even when they don't appear. For GoT there have been episodes where main cast members don't appear and aren't credited, so it may work differently for them.

The Friends cast only made $1 million an episode in its final seasons.
However they still make a ton from syndication.
